# <span style="color: #2F6050;"> Topic 2: Brief Introduction to Copulas </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}

<!------------------------------ Slide 8 ------------------------------
## <span style="color: #2F6050;"> Sklar's Thereom </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 10em;">
Sklar's Theorem states that any multivariate cumulative distribution function 
</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0em;">
$$H(x_1,...,x_d)$$ 
</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
can be represented by a copula $C$ and its marginal distributions:
</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0em;">
$$H(x_1,...,x_d) = C(F_1(x_1),...,F_d(x_d))$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-bottom: 1em;">
where C is the CDF of the copula. 
---->
<!------------------------------ Slide 9 ---------------------------------->
## <span style="color: #2F6050;"> Copulas </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}
<span style="font-size: 20px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 1.0; display: block; text-align: right; margin: 0;">
"A function which joins or 'couples' multivariate distribution function to its one-dimensional marginal distribution functions." - Roger Nelson 
</span>

</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 3em;">
Let
$F \in \mathfrak{F}(F_1, ..., F_d)$
be a d-multivariate distribution, and $F_j$ be the $j$th univariate margin for $j = 1,...,d$. <br>
</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The copula associated with $F$ is a distribution function $C:[0,1]^d \rightarrow [0,1]$ such that: 
</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0;">
$$F(x) =  C(F_1(x_1), ..., F_d(x_d))  =  C(u_1,..., u_d))  \qquad \text{where} \qquad x\in \mathbb{R}^d \qquad$$ 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Let 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0;">
$$X_1,...,X_d \sim F_1,...,F_d$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
then 
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0;">
$$\qquad F_j(X_j) \quad = \quad U_j \qquad \text{are uniformly distributed} \qquad \text{for} \quad j = 1,...,d \quad $$ 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
and 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0;">
$$U_1,...,U_d \sim C$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
Moreover, if $F$ is a continuous $d$-variate distribution function with univariate margins $F_1,...,F_d$, and quantile functions $F^{-1}_1,...,F^{-1}_d$, then 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin: 0;">
$$C(u) \quad = \quad F(F^{-1}_1(u_1),...,F^{-1}_d(u_d)), \qquad u\in [0,1]^d$$</span> 
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
is the unique copula of $F$. 
</span>

<!------------------------------ Slide 10 ---------------------------------->
## <span style=" font-size: 50px; color: #2F6050;">Common Copulas</span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}
<span style=" font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050;">Copula contour with Kendall's $\tau = 0.7$</span>

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="25%"}
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
Gaussian Copula
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The multivariate Gaussian copula cdf is: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$C_{\Sigma}(u,\Sigma) \quad = \quad \Phi_d(\Phi^{-1}(u_1),...\Phi^{-1}(u_d); \Sigma)$$ 
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where 
</span>

<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
 - $\Phi_d(\cdot)$ is the multivariate Gaussian distribution CDF <br>
</span>
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
![](gaussian_copula_contour.png){ width=50% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
t-Copula
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The multivariate t-copula cdf is: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$C_{\nu, \Sigma}(u_1,...,u_d) = T_{\nu,\Sigma}(T^{-1}_\nu(u_1),...T^{-1}_\nu(u_d))$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
 - $T_{\nu,\Sigma}(\cdot)$ is the multivariate t-distribution CDF
</span>
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
![](t_copula_contour.png){ width=50% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
:::
::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="25%"}
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
Frank Copula
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The multivariate Frank copula cdf is: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$C(u_1, u_2,...,u_d; \theta) = -\frac{1}{\theta}ln\left(1+\frac{\prod_{i=1}^d(1-e^{-\theta u_i})}{(e^{-\theta}-1)}\right)$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
 - $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$ is the copula parameter which determines the strength and type of dependence
</span>
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
![](frank_copula_contour.png){ width=50% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
Gumbel Copula
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The multivariate Gumbel copula cdf is: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$C_\theta(u_1, u_2, ..., u_d) \quad = \quad exp\left(-\left[\sum_{i=1}^d(-ln \; u_i)^\theta\right]^{1/\theta}\right)$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
 - $\theta > 1$ is the dependence strength parameter 
</span>
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
![](gumbel_copula_contour.png){ width=50% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
:::
::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="25%"}
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
Reflected Gumbel Copula
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The multivariate Reflected Gumbel copula cdf is: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$C_\theta(u_1, u_2, ..., u_d) \quad = \quad exp\left(-\left[\sum_{i=1}^d(-ln (1-u_i))^\theta\right]^{1/\theta}\right)$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
 - $\theta$ is the dependence strength parameter $\theta > 1$
</span>
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
![](rgumbel_copula_contour.png){ width=50% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
Clayton Copula
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
The multivariate Clayton copula cdf is: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$C_\theta(u_1,...,u_d) \quad = \quad \left( \sum_{i=1}^{d}u_i^{-\theta} - d + 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta}}$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
 - $\theta \geq 0$ is the copula parameter that controls the degree of dependence between the variables
</span>
:::
::: {.column width="25%"}
![](clayton_copula_contour.png){ width=50% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
:::

## <span style="color: #2F6050; margin-bottom: 1em; display: block;"> Factor Copulas </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
In the copula model with $p$ factors, the transformed variables 
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$U_1,...,U_d = F_1(X_1),...,F_d(X_d)$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
are regarded as independent conditional on $p$ latent variables $V_1,...,V_p$. Then we have: </span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$
C(u_1,...u_d) = \underbrace{\int_...\int}_\text{p}\prod_{k=1}^{d}F_{k|V_1,...V_p}(u_k|v_1,...v_p)dv_1...dv_p
$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where $F_{k|V_1,...V_p}(u_k|v_1,...v_p)$ can be expressed as a function of bi-variate copulas, conditional distribution of \textbf{U} given latent variables \textbf{V}.
</span>
<br>

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](one_factor_copula.png){ width=65% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](two_factor_copula.png){ width=100% style="display: block; margin: auto;" }
:::
:::

# <span style="color: #B7A137;"> Topic 3: Model Construction and Results </span>{background-color="#FCF9ED"}
## <span style="color: #B7A137;"> Preliminary Steps</span>{background-color="#FCF9ED"}
::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
<span style="font-size: 20px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
ARMA-GARCH Filtering 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
$ARMA(p,q)$ <br>
Let <br>
- $y_t$ denote the time-series value at time $t$ <br>
- $\epsilon_t$ denote the error term (white noise) at time $t$ where $E(\epsilon_t) = 0$ and $Var(\epsilon_t) = \sigma^2$ <br>
Then:
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #B7A137; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$y_t = \mu + \phi_1y_{t-1} + \phi_2y_{t-2} + \cdots + \rho_p y_{t-p} + \epsilon_t$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; 
: 1em;">
where <br> <br>
- $p$ is the order of the AR component <br>
- $q$ is the order of the MA component <br>
- $\epsilon_t$ is the error term at time $t$, assumed to follow a white noise process with zero mean and constant variance
</span>


<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
$GARCH(p,q)$ <br>
Let <br>
- $\sigma_t$ denote error variance term at time $t$ <br>
Then:
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #B7A137; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$\sigma^2_t = \alpha_0 + \alpha_1 y^2_{t-1} + ... + \alpha_p y^2_{t-p} + \beta_1 \sigma^2_{t-1} + ... + \beta_q \sigma^2_{t-q}$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
where <br> <br>
- $\alpha_{0} > 0$ and $\alpha_i \geq 0$ for $i = 1, \dots, p$ <br>
- $\beta_0 > 0$ and $\beta_i \geq 0$ for $i = 1,....,q$ <br>
</span>

:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
<span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em; display: block;">
Ljung-Box Test: <br>
$H_0$:There are no autocorrelations in the series <br>
$H_1$: There are autocorrelations present in the series 
</span>

<div style="font-size: 10px; color: black; line-height: 0.6; margin-top: 1em; text-align: center;">
  <table style="margin: 0 auto; border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%;">
    <tr>
      <th style="padding: 8px; border-bottom: 1px solid black; border-top: 1px solid black;">Asset</th>
      <th style="padding: 8px; border-bottom: 1px solid black; border-top: 1px solid black;">ARMA-GARCH</th>
      <th style="padding: 8px; border-bottom: 1px solid black; border-top: 1px solid black; font-weight: normal;">
  <span style="font-weight: bold; line-height :1.5; ">P-Values</span> <br> Ljung-Box Test on Squared Residuals

## <span style="color: #B7A137; font-size: 50px"> Model 1 - Standard One Factor Copula Model</span>{background-color="#FCF9ED"}
<span style="font-size: 20px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Model Setup 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
In a one factor copula, we assume our variables of interest 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #B7A137;; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$X_{i1},...,X_{id} \in \mathbb{R} \qquad \text{ for } i = 1,...,n$$ 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
have been transformed to uniform random variables using their respective univariate marginal distributions
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #B7A137;; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$U_{i1},...,U_{id} \sim Uniform(0,1) \qquad \text{ for } i = 1,...,n $$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
We further assume that $U_{i1},...,U_{id}$ are conditionally independent given the latent variable $V_1$, and we assume $V_1 \sim Uniform(0,1)$ <br>
Then, let $F_{U_j|V_1}$ denote the conditional cumulative distribution function of $U_j$ given $V_1$, we have: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #B7A137;; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$
    F_{X_1,...,X_d}(x_{i1},...,x_{id}) = C(u_{i1},...,u_{id}) = \int_0^1 \prod_{j=1}^{d}F_{U_j|V_1}(u_{ij}|v_{1})dv_1  = \int_0^1 \prod_{j=1}^{d}C_{U_j|V_1}(u_{ij}|v_{1})dv_1
$$
</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Since $U_j$ and $V_1$ are $Uniform(0,1)$ random variables, and 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #B7A137;; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$F_{U_j|V_1} (u_{ij}|v_{1}) = \frac{\partial }{\partial V_1}C_{U_j,V_1}(u_j,v_1) = C_{U_j|V_1}(u_j|v_1)$$ 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Therefore,  
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #B7A137;; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$c(u_{i1},...,u_{id}) = \frac{\partial^d}{\partial u_{i1},...,u_{id}}C(u_{i1},...,u_{id}) = \int_0^1\prod_{j=1}^d c_{U_j, V_1}(u_{ij},v_{1})dv_1$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: black; line-height: 1.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
since 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #B7A137;; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$\frac{\partial}{\partial u_{ij}}C_{U_j|V_1}(u_{ij}|v_{1}) = \frac{\partial^2}{\partial U_j \partial V_1} C_{U_j, V_1}(u_{ij},v_{1}) = c_{U_j, V_1}(u_{ij},v_{1})$$
</span>

## <span style="color: #B7A137; font-size: 55px;"> Model 1 - Standard One Factor Copula Model</span>{background-color="#FCF9ED"}
<span style="font-size: 20px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Model Results 
</span>
<span style="color: black; font-size: 14px;">
The tail weighted measure of dependence is defined as: 
</span>
<span style="color: #B7A137; font-size: 14px;">
\begin{equation} \label{eq:tail_weighted_measure_of_dependence}
\rho_L(a,p) = Cor\left( a\left(1 - \frac{1-U_1}{p}\right), a\left(1 - \frac{1-U_2}{p}\right) \middle| U_1 < p, U_2 < p \right)
\end{equation}
$$\rho_U(a,p)= Cor\left ( a\left(1 - \frac{1-U_1}{p}\right), a\left(1  - \frac{1-U_2}{p}\right) \middle| 1-U_1 < p, 1- U_2 < p\right)$$
</span>
<span style="color: black; font-size: 14px; line-height :2; display:block;">
where <br>
    - $\rho_U$ and $\rho_L$ are the upper and lower tail-weighted dependence measures <br>
    - $a(\cdot)$ : $[0,1]\rightarrow (0,\infty)$ is a continuous function <br>
    - $p$ is the truncation level satisfying $0<p\leq 0.5$ <br>
</span>

::: {.columns} 
::: {.column width="30%"}
<span style="color: black; font-size: 14px; line-height :1.5; display:block;">
We take $a$ to be the power function $a(u) = u^k$ and define squared errors for the tail-weighted measure of dependence as follows:
</span>

<span style="color: #B7A137; font-size: 14px;">
$$
\text{SE Upper Tail} = \sum_i^d\sum_j^d(\rho_{U; i,j}^{\text{simulated}} - \rho_{U; i,j}^{\text{observed}})^2 \\
\text{SE Lower Tail} = \sum_i^d\sum_j^d(\rho_{L; i,j}^{\text{simulated}} - \rho_{L; i,j}^{\text{observed}})^2
$$
</span>

:::
::: {.column width="70%"}

## <span style="color: #B7A137; font-size: 55px;"> Model 2 - Dynamic Dependence Structure </span>{background-color="#FCF9ED"}
<span style="font-size: 20px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Model Setup 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: black; line-height: 2; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
Non-parametric, dynamic modelling of the dependence parameters. <br> <br>
Find the maximum likelihood estimators $\widehat{\theta}_{jTd_m}$ for $j = 1,..,p$ and $d_m \in {T,...,N}$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: #B7A137; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$L(\mathbf{u_1},...,\mathbf{u_d};  \theta_{1Td_m},..., \theta_{dTd_m}) = \prod_{i=d_m-T+1}^{d_m} \int_0^1\prod_{j=1}^d c_{U_j, V_1}(u_{ij},v_{1}; \theta_{jTd_m})dv_{1}$$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: black; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
T is the rolling-window size. <br>
By minimizing the negative of the log likelihood below: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: #B7A137; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$l(\mathbf{u_1},..,\mathbf{u_d}; \theta_{1Td_m},..., \theta_{dTd_m}) = \sum_{i=d_m-T+1}^{d_m} log\left(\int_0^1\prod_{j=1}^dc_{U_{j}, V_{1}}(u_{ij}, v_{1}; \theta_{jTd_m})dv_{1}\right)$$
</span>

# <span style="color: #2F6050;"> Topic 4: Computational Details </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}
<!------------------Slide 24-------------------------------->
## <span style="color: #2F6050; font-size: 55px;"> Computational Complexity of the One Factor Copula Model</span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}

<span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
The likelihood function for the **one factor copula model** with $n$ observations and $d$ variables is defined as: 
</span>

<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
$$L(\mathbf{u_1},...,\mathbf{u_d}; \theta_1,...\theta_d) = \prod_{i=1}^n \int_0^1\prod_{j=1}^d c_{U_j, V_1}(u_{ij},v_1; \theta_j)dv_{1}$$ 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">

<span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">Computing the likelihood for a factor copula model can be **computationally expensive**
for several reasons <br>
<ul style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-left:3em; line-height: 2">
  <li>For **each observation each variable**, we need to compute the values of all the bi-variate copula density</li>
  <li>The product of the $d$ bivariate copula densities must be **integrated out with respect to the latent variable** using the Gauss-Legendre method <br> e.g. for each observation $i$ and $m$ number of quadrature points, we need to compute $m \times d$ number of bi-variate copula densities
  <li> The likelihood function needs to be evaluated **multiple times** to find the optimal value</li>
</ul>
</span>
e.g. with 2,000 observations, 20 variables and 35 quadrenture points, we need to compute 1.4 million bivariate copula densities; if the optimization algorithm converges in 100 iterations, the total number of calculations becomes 140 million 
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Furthermore, the derivative of the log likelihood function with respect to a parameter $\theta_k$ can be derived as: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
$$\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_k}l(\mathbf{u_1},..,\mathbf{u_d}; \theta_1,..., \theta_d) = \sum_{i=1}^n \left\{\frac{\int_0^1\prod_{j\neq k}c_{U_j,V_{1}}(u_{ij}, v_{1}, \theta_j) \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_k}c_{u_k, v_1}(u_{ik}, v_{1}; \theta_k)dv_{1}}{\int_0^1\prod_{j = 1}^d c_{U_j,V_{1}}
(u_{ij}, v_{1}, \theta_j)}   \right\} $$
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: em;">
For each iteration of the optimization process, we must compute $n \times d \times m$ bi-variate copula values and their corresponding derivatives for each model parameter, further compounding the computational cost. 
</span>

<!------------------Slide 25-------------------------------->
## <span style="color: #2F6050; font-size: 55px;"> Optimization Strategies </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: black; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 5em;">
<ul style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-left:3em">
  <li>**Use of Gauss-Legendre Method for Numerical Integration**</li>
  <li>**Extensive Use of Matrix Operations with Efficient Packages**</li>
  <li>**Efficient Product Calculation Using apply(), mapply() and do.call()**</li>
  <li>**Mathematical Techniques**</li>
  <li>**Efficient Handling of Gradients**</li>
  <li>**Reuse of Intermediate Calculations**</li>
  <li>**Use of Parallel Processing**</li>
  <li>**Use of Rcpp for C++ Functions**</li>
</ul>

<!------------------Slide 26-------------------------------->
## <span style="color: #2F6050; font-size: 55px;"> Optimization Strategies (Cont'd) </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 5em;">
<ul style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-left:3em">
  <li>**Use of Gauss-Legendre Method for Numerical Integration**</li>
  <ul style="margin-top: 0.2em; margin-left: 1em;">
  <span style="font-size: 15px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
    <li>In the Gauss-Legendre method, the integral of a function $f(x)$ over the interval $[-1,1]$ with $\mathbf{m}$ **number of quadrature points** is approximated as: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$\int_{-1}^{1}f(x)dx \approx \sum_{k=1}^{m}w_kf(x_k)$$ 
</span>
  </ul>
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
  <li>**Extensive Use of Matrix Operations**</li>
</span>
  <ul style="margin-top: 0.2em; margin-left: 1em;">
    <span style="font-size: 15px; color: black; line-height: 1.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
    <li> For example, to perform the numerical integration in both the likelihood and the derivative functions, we define a matrix $V \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times m}$ 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
    $$V = 
    \begin{bmatrix}
      v_{11} & v_{12} & \cdots & v_{1m} \\
      v_{21} & v_{22} & \cdots & v_{2m} \\
      \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\
      v_{d1} & v_{d2} & \cdots & v_{dm}
    \end{bmatrix}
    $$
     </span>
    <span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
    <ul style="margin-top: 0.2em; margin-left: 1em;">
    
    <li> Gauss-Legendre quadrature points are replicated across observations </li>
    <li> Elliminate the need to recalculate these values for every loop iteration, leveraging vectorized computations </li>
    <li> The integral is also recycled to calculate both the likelihood function value as well as the derivative </li>
    </ul>
  </li>
  </ul>
</ul> 

## <span style="color: #2F6050; font-size: 45px;"> Optimization Strategies (Cont'd) </span>{background-color="#ECFADC"}
<span style="font-size: 18px; color: black; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
<ul style="margin-top: 0.2em; margin-left: 1em; margin-bottom:0em;">
  <li>**Mathematical Techniques**</li>
  <ul style="margin-top: 0.2em; margin-left: 1em; margin-top: 0em">
    <span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 2.0; display: block; margin-top: 0em;">
    <li> **Gaussian One Factor Copula**: the $j \neq k$ term cancels<br>
    </span>
    <span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
<ul style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-left:3em">
    $$
    \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho_k}l(\mathbf{u_1},..,\mathbf{u_d}; \rho_1,..., \rho_d) = \sum_{i=1}^n \left\{\frac{\int_0^1\prod_{j=1}^dc_{U_j,V_{1}}(u_{ij}, v_{1}, \rho_j) \frac{\rho_k(1-\rho_k^2) + \Phi^{-1}(u_{ik})\Phi^{-1}(v_{1})(1+\rho_k^2) - \rho_k(\Phi^{-1}(u_{ik})^2 + \Phi^{-1}(v_{1})^2)}{(1-\rho_k^2)^2}dv_{1}}{\int_0^1\prod_{j=1}^dc_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \rho_k) dv_{1}}   \right\}
    $$
    </span>
    </li>
  </ul>
  <span style="font-size: 12px; color: black; line-height: 2; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
  <li> **Gumbel and Clayton One Factor Copula** <br>
  </span>
  <span style="margin-left: 20px; line-height:2;">Problem: The $j \neq k$ term does not cancel</span><br>
    <span style="margin-left: 20px; line-height:2;">Solution:</span> 
  </span>

<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
$$
    A = 
    \begin{bmatrix}
        c_{U_1,V_{1}}(u_{i1}, v_{1}) & c_{U_2,V_{1}}(u_{i2}, v_{1}) & \cdots & c_{U_d,V_{1}}(u_{id}, v_{1}) \\ 
        c_{U_1,V_{1}}(u_{i1}, v_{1}) & c_{U_2,V_{1}}(u_{i2}, v_{1}) & \cdots & c_{U_d,V_{1}}(u_{id}, v_{1}) \\ 
        \vdots                       & \vdots                         & \vdots & \vdots                        \\
        c_{U_1,V_{1}}(u_{i1}, v_{1}) & c_{U_2,V_{1}}(u_{i2}, v_{1}) & \cdots & c_{U_d,V_{1}}(u_{id}, v_{1})
    \end{bmatrix}
    \qquad
    B = 
    \begin{bmatrix}
        c_{U_1,V_{1}}(u_{i1}, v_{1}) & c_{U_2,V_{1}}(u_{i2}, v_{1}) & \cdots & c_{U_d,V_{1}}(u_{id}, v_{1})
    \end{bmatrix}
$$
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: black; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 2em;">
so that when we compute the column products of the matrix A, the matrix becomes: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
\begin{align*}
    A_{prod}= 
    \begin{bmatrix}
        \prod_{j=1}^dc_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \theta_k)  & \prod_{j=1}^dc_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \theta_k) & \cdots & \prod_{j=1}^dc_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \theta_k) \\ 
    \end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
Finally, dividing by the row vector B, we have: 
</span>
<span style="font-size: 14px; color: #2F6050; line-height: 2.5; display: block; margin-top: 1em;">
\begin{align*}
    \frac{A_{prod}}{B} = 
    \begin{bmatrix}
        \prod_{j \neq 1}c_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \theta_k)  & \prod_{j \neq 2}c_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \theta_k) & \cdots & \prod_{j \neq d}c_{U_k,V_{1}}(u_{ik}, v_{1}, \theta_k) \\ 
    \end{bmatrix} \\
    \\
\end{align*}
  </ul>
</ul>
</span>
</li>
